t: A psalm. A song for the Sabbath day.
It*pn is good to give thanks to the Lord,*s to*ln sing praise to your name, Most High,
to*ln declare your faithful love in the morning and*ln your faithfulness at night,
with*ln a ten-stringed harp and*ln the music of a lyre.
For*pn you have made me rejoice, Lord,*s by*ln what you have done; I*ln will shout for joy because*ln of the works of your hands.
How*ln magnificent are your works, Lord,*s how*ln profound your thoughts!
A*ln stupid person does not know, a*ln fool does not understand this:
though*ln the wicked sprout like grass and*ln all evildoers flourish, they*ln will be eternally destroyed.
But*ln you, Lord,*s are exalted forever.
For*ln indeed, Lord,*s your enemies — indeed,*ln your enemies will perish; all*ln evildoers will be scattered.
You*ln have lifted up my horn like*ln that of a wild ox; I*ln have been anointed with the finest oil.
My*ln eyes look at my enemies; when*ln evildoers rise against me, my*ln ears hear them.
The*pn righteous thrive like a palm tree and*ln grow like a cedar tree in Lebanon.
Planted*ln in the house of the Lord,*s they*ln thrive in the courts of our God.
They*ln will still bear fruit in old age, healthy*ln and green,
to*ln declare, “The Lord*s is just; he*ln is my rock, and*ln there is no unrighteousness in him.”
